plist.p: Well good morning, London, and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and in Mumbai. I'm pleased to report that the bank has again performed strongly in the first six months of 2012, our tenth consecutive first half of record profits. Set against a macroeconomic environment that is increasingly challenged, these results are very strong results. And let me emphasize, this is a story of continued and consistent delivery from an institution in the tenth year of unbroken growth.

Once again, it seems that the world is becoming more uncertain by the day. Nonetheless, our focus will remain, as always, resolutely on the interests of our shareholders. And I would like to reiterate that we have a firm grip on the business, with the ability to turn adversity to our advantage. And we will keep investing as we see long-term opportunities for growth.

In recent weeks, issues have surfaced around governance and behavior in banking. At Standard Chartered, we believe it's not just about what we do, but how we do it. Our culture and our values continue to be a source of strength and competitive advantage. Strong corporate governance and an obsession with the basics of banking remain key areas of focus for our board. Now in a moment, Richard will walk you through the numbers, and then Peter will talk about our strategy and outlook.

But first, let me comment on a few highlights of our performance. Income rose 9% to $9.51 billion with profits before taxation up 9% to $3.95 billion and normalized earnings per share up 11% to 116.6 cents. With return on equity at 13.8%, we remain on target to reach our key financial objective of mid-teens return on equity over the medium-term.
We are again increasing the total amount of dividend paid to shareholders. The board has declared an interim dividend of $0.273 per share, which is up 10%.

Standard Chartered is in the right markets with the right strategy and we have the right leadership in place. That is why we remain confident in the bank's ability to deliver sustained good returns and we thank our shareholders for their continued support. Now, with all the noise going on around us, we are determined not to become distracted and to remain our focus on doing good business.

We continue to support our customers and clients, deepening our long-term relationships with them. I'd like to take this opportunity to thank our customers and our clients for their trust and commitment to banking with Standard Chartered.
Let me now ask Richard to walk you through the results in more detail. Richard?

Thank you, John. Good morning, London, and good afternoon, Hong Kong and Mumbai. What I'm presenting today is another strong set of results. Our track record of consistent delivery has continued despite the challenges in the external environment. And these results are in line with previous guidance. There are no surprises.

We have a firm grip on the management levers of costs and investment and of risk. We continue to manage the business conservatively. Our balance sheet strength, strong capital and liquidity position and our ability to access unsecured funding are key competitive advantages, enabling us to support our clients through turbulent times.

Economic growth, while slowing, still remains strong because our footprint markets of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. As we continue to manage the business tightly, we are further stepping up investment spend to position us strongly for the long-term growth opportunities we see across our markets.

Let me draw out several key highlights. The group has delivered strong income and profit growth over the first half of 2011 (sic) [2012] (5:36), both up 9% and this against a background of a slowing global economy and currency headwinds. On a constant currency basis, both income and profit were up by a double-digit rate, showing the strong underlying beat of our business.

Costs have been tightly controlled and we have delivered positive cost income jaws, which round to 2%, providing the additional capacity to accelerate investment in both businesses. Our balance sheet remains in excellent shape, with an A-D ratio and liquid asset ratio of 77.6% and 27.9%, respectively.

Customer loans and advances and total deposits have each grown 4% on the year-end position and risk-weighted assets have grown 6%. Continued capital strength with core Tier 1 at 11.6% and total capital at 16.9%. Normalized earnings per share has risen 11% to 116.6 cents.

We've declared an interim dividend of $0.2723 per share, up 10%, and we continue to make good progress on improving returns, for our shareholders' return-on-equity is 13.8%, or 13.3% after adjusting for an estimated deduction for the UK bank levy. Let me take you through the numbers.

At a group level, income has grown strongly, up 9% on the first half of 2011 and within this, consumer banking income was up 5%, while wholesale banking income increased 10%, with broad growth was up in multiple products and customer segments. The growth has been impacted by just under 3% as an income level by local currency weakness, particularly the Indian rupee, which alone accounts for a 1.6% drag on income.

Expenses are up 6% year-on-year and 9% on a constant currency basis. We look to increase investments in the second half of the year, particularly in our systems and our distribution network and we will focus on enhancing customer experience and service.

While loan impairment has increased, it remains low and reflects the gradual and planned mix shift in consumer banking assets towards unsecured and also, provisions taken against a very small number of wholesale banking exposures.

Operating profit of $3.948 billion increased 9% on the first half of 2011. The group's effective tax rate in the first half of the year was 26.5%, and this is lower than the 2011 full year effective tax rate as a result of geographic profit mix and the impact of the branch profits exemption election made last year. And overall, the group has had a record first half, with the performance underpinned by the diversity of our business and the continued economic growth across our markets.

The diversity of the group give us real resilience. Our multiple engines of growth enable us to grow at pace, even when some geographies or products have weaker years. Despite the macroeconomic environment, 20 markets grew at a double-digit pace. Our largest market, Hong Kong, which grew income at 10%, contributed just 18% to the group's income in the first half of 2012.

By product, we've seen double-digit income growth in credit cards, in personal loans, in deposits, in rates, and in the heart of our wholesale banking business, trade and cash management. And we continue to invest in our product capabilities. For example, we are the market leader in renminbi, and we are pioneering areas of automation for the benefit of our clients in trade finance.

Moving to the balance sheet. The balance sheet is in excellent shape and continues to be highly liquid, well diversified, strongly capitalized, and a source of real competitive advantage. We remain firmly open for business, actively deploying our balance sheet strength to support our customers and clients.

The group remains primarily deposit-funded, growing deposits in both business despite strong market competition in some of our key geographies. Total deposits are up 4% on the year-end position, as we benefit from being the only major international bank to be upgraded by all three rating agencies since the onset of the financial crisis. We have limited refinancing requirements over the next few years and only some $3 billion through to the end of 2013.

We have continued to see good support from the capital markets, with two subordinated Tier 2 and one senior unsecured transaction closed so far in 2012. And all three transactions were heavily over-subscribed, reflecting the strong and continuing demand in the market for our name.

Our liquid asset ratio was at 27.9% and we already meet the minimum Basel III requirement for both the net stable funding ratio and the liquidity coverage ratio. We have some $174 billion of liquid assets.

Turning to assets, we continue to see good growth momentum, with our customer loans and advances up 4% since the year-end. We have in consumer banking a continuing bias to secured lending, with 82% of the book being either fully or partially secured. We have a low loan-to-value ratio on our mortgage book of 48%; a short maturity profile on our wholesale banking customer loan book, with 63% of the book under one year in tenure, reflecting the continued trade bias of our business.

And we have no direct sovereign exposure to Portugal, Italy, Ireland, Greece or Spain, and our total gross exposure to these countries remains immaterial at around 0.5% of total assets. Our loan portfolio remains well-diversified, both by geography and by sector, and conservatively positioned.

Moving to capital. The group remains well-capitalized, with a core Tier 1 of 11.6%, a Tier 1 ratio of 13.4%, and total capital of 16.9%. In the first half, we have generated $2.8 billion of profit attributable to ordinary shareholders. The capital ratios have been affected by a number of factors, including the final dividend, where there was a lower scrip take-up than we have historically seen. Growth in risk-weighted assets of 6% including the impact of some negative credit migration, an element of drag from structural foreign exchange, and the acquisition of shares to support long-term staff incentive schemes. In July, we issued $1.25 billion of lower Tier 2 capital and including this issuance, our total capital ratio would be above 17%, at 17.3%.

Looking now at performance by business and starting with consumer banking. The consumer banking transformation program continues to make good progress and we are investing in the business in order to grow both our customer base and customer service capabilities. Consumer banking customer footings have grown over the year-end level, with customer deposits up 3% and loans and advances up 1%. Loans and advances growth was impacted by a decline in mortgage balances in Korea, in particular.

Income grew 5% year-on-year to $3.5 billion. There's slightly lower momentum than in the past. Income growth has been impacted by muted performances in India, Korea and Taiwan. However, China and Indonesia, but also Africa, and the Americas, UK and Europe region are all growing income at a good double-digit rate.

Expenses increased 9%, although the comparative period included $86 million of non-recurring cost recoveries made against structured net provisions. Excluding this, expenses grew 5% year-on-year. As we see opportunities to grow, we are investing in marketing, in infrastructure and building out our network, in particular, in Africa and in China. We have completed 56 branch projects in the first half, including new branches, branch relocations, refurbishments and some closures. And we've also continued to invest in enhancing our mobile and Internet banking capabilities.

The consumer banking loan impairment charge has increased in line with expectations and I will go into this in detail later. As a result of the lower overall performance momentum, one-off expense recoveries in the comparable period of 2011, and higher loan impairments, consumer banking operating profit has fallen 11%.

Turning to product. Mortgage income was down 13% against the first half of 2011, with balances down 1% on the year-end position and compression in margins. Overall margins have fallen some 19 basis points year-on-year and are rising particularly in Hong Kong, Korea, Africa and China. Mortgage income has been impacted by regulatory cooling measures in several key markets.

Deposit income is up strongly, 14% year-on-year, driven by an improvement in margins of some 10 basis points and an increase in balances of 3% on the year-end position and despite increasing competition for liabilities across many of our markets.

Wealth management the income was down 3% year-on-year, due to weaker investor sentiment given the slowing global economy and market volatility, and the geographies most affected here were Taiwan and Korea.

Moving to the next slide. Income in credit cards and personal loans shows excellent momentum, up 13% year-on-year, as we continue to grow balances, up 7% since the year-end. We are enjoying steady market share gains in credit card spend, particularly in Hong Kong and in personal loans in Hong Kong and in Korea.

SME continues to perform well, with 7% income growth year-on-year driven by lending, trade, and cash management. The SME book remains predominantly secured. We continue to increase our lending to SMEs with loans and advances up 3% on the year-end position.

Moving to impairment. Loan impairment has increased year-on-year, in line with expectations, reflecting growth in the portfolio and mix change. Loan impairment increased 42% on the first half of 2011 to $300 million, but is down marginally on the level seen in the second half.

Loan impairments benefited in the first half by some $43 million from sales of previously written down portfolios, in line with the average level seen in 2011. We remain comfortable with our exposures and continue to proactively manage our book. Our forward-looking indicators have actually marginally improved on the level seen in the second half of 2011.

So, to summarize for consumer banking, balance sheet momentum has slowed and we are seeing pressures in wealth management and in mortgages. However, deposits and unsecured are growing well. Costs and risk are under tight control and loan impairment is growing in line with our expectations. We have identified accelerated investment opportunities to underpin continued growth in the future.

Looking at wholesale banking. Wholesale banking has delivered another outstanding performance, reflecting the resilience of the business model, the continued business activity of our client base, and underlying growth within our footprint. Income was up 10% and client income up 8% on the first half of 2011, which was itself a very strong period. Client income contributes 80% of total wholesale banking income, with over 70% generated from our corporate client base and the balance from financial institutions.

Our sustained performance is built on our traditional foundation of commercial banking, which contributes over 50% of wholesale banking client income and provides us with a strong platform to engage with our clients, often on a daily basis. As well as giving us an unparalleled view of the client's business, it gives us real opportunities to expand our relationship across other product lines.

As we sit at both ends of the major global trade and investment flows, our network and the interconnectivity of our markets remain sources of competitive differentiation, with 51% of client income in the first half of 2012 being network revenue.

The strength of our client relationships, often built over decades, gives us real competitive advantage. We continue to invest in client service capabilities, including a new but significant and multi-year upgrade of our cash management system and a standardized relationship management platform, and we will further accelerate investment in the second half of 2012.

Own account income increased 21% year-on-year. This is driven by principal finance, which was up 59%, mainly on valuation gains and by ALM income, up 14%. ALM income growth reflects a larger balance sheet and an improving yield opportunity. As a client-focused bank, our trading activities are centered on executing the high levels of client flows we generate. We have no proprietary trading desks.
Expenses rose 3%, primarily reflecting strong control on business-as-usual costs, creating investment capacity for the second half. And operating profit increased an excellent 16% year-on-year.

Looking at income in more detail. Our core transaction banking business has had a strong first half, with income up 19%, accounting for over three-quarters of total wholesale banking client income growth. We have deepened further our focus on transaction banking as our core business, a pivot from which other products are sold.

In trade, income was up an excellent 25%, driven by growth in average assets and contingents of 13% year-on-year and an increase in margins of some 17 basis points. Intra-Asia trade continues to grow at a faster rate than global trade, which is expected to be lower in 2012 than in 2011. We continue to take market share as our network capability differentiates us.
Cash management income saw strong growth of 13%, underpinned both by growth in average balances, up 11%, and an improvement in cash margins of seven basis points against the first half of last year.

Corporate finance income was up 9% on the first half of 2011. This business is increasingly diversified, with an increase in the number of transactions closed year-on-year. The deal pipeline remains very strong, indeed, a record by both number and value, although there is clearly execution risk, given the challenging external environment.

Financial markets. Income in financial markets was up 2% on the first half of 2011. This is a strong performance in light of difficult market conditions impacting the industry and FICC, in particular. Our FICC income was up 1% year-on-year and 15% on the second half of 2011, further highlighting our core banking strategy and commercial banking foundation, albeit quarter two was down on quarter one.
Foreign exchange income of $743 million fell 3% as a result of muted volumes, reduced volatility and a higher proportion of business transacted with financial institutions.

The rates business grew income by 20% year-on-year to $539 million, due to the increased appetite of our corporate clients to hedge their positions and as a result of higher levels of interest rate volatility. Commodities and equities income fell 13% when compared to a strong first half of 2011, impacted by low volatility and the non-repeat of several large client transactions completed in that comparable period.

Capital markets income increased 7% year-on-year to $290 million. The uncertain macro environment narrowed the window for issuers to access the market, resulting in lower syndicated loan volumes, somewhat offset by an increase in bond volumes. Credit and other income was up 1% on the first half of 2011, again, on the back of lower volatility.

Moving to loan impairment, overall, net loan impairment remains low at 36 basis points of loans and advances to customers. Loan impairment has, however, increased 41% year-on-year, owing to provisions made on a very small number of exposures. More than 80% of these provisions are from a very small number of accounts in the UAE related to general macroeconomic factors and in India, relating to both macroeconomic and more specific political factors. We are not currently seeing any signs of stress and we remain comfortable with our cover ratios in particular, reflecting the quality of underlying collateral and our historic recovery rates.

Though the alerts have increased on the year-end position, given our proactive starts on managing risks in a more uncertain environment. In addition to our normal monitoring, we have conducted deep dives in a number of geographies and sectors and credit quality across the wholesale banking book as a whole remains strong.

Our wholesale banking loan book is conservative, diverse by geography and by sector and predominantly short-dated, where 63% of loans and advances have a tenure of less than one year. We have low exposure to problematic clauses, ABS, leveraged loans and Level 3 assets, and our commercial real estate portfolio of $10.4 billion has an average loan-to-value of 46%.

To summarize, wholesale banking has delivered another strong set of results and there is very good underlying business momentum, with record deal pipelines and continued strong growth in our core businesses of trade and cash.

We continue to have a firm grip on costs, enabling further accelerated investment in the second half, and we remain proactive in the management of risk. We are positioned in the growth markets of the world. We have strong core banking relationships and we are offering support to our clients and customers as they grow.

Turning to geographic performance. Peter will talk to you about Africa, about China and the Americas, UK and Europe region. However, let me highlight some of our other geographies. Hong Kong has continued to deliver and has finished the first half strongly, achieving double-digit income growth. The performance is broad-based. Wholesale banking delivered a strong performance, particularly in transaction banking and corporate finance. And we continued to benefit the mere emergence of the renminbi and from Hong Kong's role as the gateway to mainland China. Consumer banking income in Hong Kong was up 5%, impacted by a fall in mortgage income, given margin compression. However, we have seen double-digit income growth in credit cards and personal loans and also deposits.

Singapore has delivered 6% income growth on a very strong comparative period, in particular in wholesale banking. We have seen strong income growth in credit cards and personal loans and in transaction banking. Given this continued income momentum, strong cost control and a fall in loan impairment, operating profit in Singapore increased 17% year-on-year.

Korea's income grew $110 million or 13%. However, this includes $74 million from a one-off property sale. We continue to see strong growth in network revenue, up 10%, as we build on our position as the international bank for Korean global corporates. Expenses in Korea are down on the levels seen in the first half of 2011, with the benefits in the early retirement program more than offsetting inflationary increases. We continue to reshape the consumer banking balance sheet in Korea. Indeed, we have recently signed an agreement with the Korea Housing Finance Corporation to transfer to them fixed rate mortgages that we originate.

Looking at India, the rupee depreciation against U.S. dollar has had a significant impact on performance, with a 14% drag on income. On a reported basis, India income was down 12% as the difficult operating environment continued onshore. Although consumer banking represents only a small part of the business, income here is up 8% on a constant currency basis, with a particularly good performance in deposits.

Within wholesale banking, we saw a strong performance from our core trade and cash businesses. The network revenue, which is reported in other geographic areas, continues to deliver good growth, up 20% year-on-year.

We maintain a cautious view on credit risk in India, given the uncertain environment, and we have stress-tested our portfolio and tightened underwriting standards. We remain optimistic with the medium term prospects and continue to invest in the business.

Within MESA, consumer banking income was up 3%, driven by good performances in SME and credit cards and personal loans. In wholesale banking, client income increased 5% with good performances in both transaction banking and corporate finance. But this was more than offset by a fall in own account income. And as a result, wholesale banking income fell 1% over the comparable period.

Costs here have been tightly controlled, up 5%. Loan impairment has increased 13%, driven by provisions taken on a very small number of accounts within wholesale banking. And as a result, operating profit for the MESA region was down 12% year-on-year.

Turning then to outlook. As we consider the outlook for the full year, it is important to bear in mind the growing turbulence and uncertainty in the global economy, particularly in the Eurozone. The material and increasing drag from an ever more complex set of regulatory requirements, and the continued strength of the U.S. dollar against Asian currencies.

So the world is increasingly difficult to forecast. However, for the group as a whole, we currently remain on course to deliver on our full year financial objectives. So double-digit revenue growth, neutral jaws, but with a positive bias, double-digit earnings per share growth and we made good progress towards our medium-term target of mid-teens return on equity, with a pre-levy return on equity at 13.8% in this first half.

We have a firm grip on the levers of risk, costs and investment, and we remain open for business. Indeed, we are proactively reaching out to support our customers and clients even more, growing our business as they grow theirs. As a result, we enter the second half with confidence. We've had a strong July, but we are watchful of the significant and growing challenges in the external world, and we are managing risk tightly.

We continue to focus on the basics of banking. We continue to invest in order to underpin future income momentum and we continue to take market share in multiple markets and across multiple products. Thank you, and now, I'll hand over to Peter.

Thank you, Richard. Good morning, and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and Mumbai. These results represent a very positive start to the year. Amidst all the turbulence in the global economy and the apparently never-ending turmoil in the world of banking, we remain consistent in continuing to deliver strong performance.

I appreciate it may seem a bit boring in contrast to what's going on elsewhere. But we see some virtue in being boring. We've stuck to our strategy, staying focused on our markets in Asia, Africa and the Middle East, supporting our customers and clients, maintaining a tight grip on the business. We've held true to our values, to the spirit of here for good, taking a long-term view, always trying to do the right thing.

Our record of consistent delivery is testament to the resilience of the bank's business model and underscores the sheer diversity of the income engines we have. These results are not a bank's bank nor flattered by big one-off items. They are just our tenth consecutive first half of record profits.

Such consistency is all the more important, and all the more remarkable, given the scale and unpredictability of the external events and trends affecting us. The avalanche of regulations shows no sign of abating and given the seemingly endless flow of bad news about the industry, the calls for yet more regulation have predictably intensified.

Meanwhile and more fundamentally, the global economy continues to weaken. The Eurozone faces profound challenges, a political and economic morass that has defied every attempt at resolution. We don't see the Eurozone's problems getting solved any time soon and every failed plan makes it more difficult to win market credibility for the next.

In the U.S., ultra low interest rates and continued fiscal largesse have undoubtedly been a tonic, but neither is sustainable. Concern is already rising about the prospect of a post-election fiscal cliff. Indeed, across the West, central banks have had to deploy an unprecedented array of tools and initiatives in an attempt to offset the effects of fiscal austerity and bank deleveraging.

But quantitative easing and the like appear to have less effect with every hit. Think how quickly the LTRO wore off. It was absolutely needed, but for €1 trillion, you would have hoped to have got more than a couple of months of feel-good factor. For too many years, the West boosted growth and at least the illusion of prosperity through ever more private debt and ever more public spending and thus, public debt.

We're now in the painful process of weaning ourselves from that addiction. But the risk is that we swap one set of drugs for another and become overly dependent on what central banks can do. Some action is undoubtedly desirable, but we are already in uncharted territory, so must be extremely thoughtful.

As we've often said before, Asia is not immune to the woes of Europe and the fragility of economic recovery in the U.S. The West is some two-thirds of the global economy and if it slows, no one is unscathed.

Yet although Asia is slowing, we remain reasonably confident about the outlook. The underlying structural drivers of growth remain robust. Urbanization, demographics, industrialization, the growth of intra-regional trade and investment. We see no dimming of Asia's longer-term growth prospects.

And while some degree of near-term slowdown appears inevitable, policymakers in many of our markets have far more room for maneuver than their counterparts in the West. Of course, the scope for policy errors in every market has its own specific issues. But at this stage, we're not expecting a sharp departure from the growth trajectory; more, some bumps in the road.

We're not complacent, but with demand for financial services growing at around twice GDP growth at this level of per capita income, and with ample room to win market share, we still see exciting prospects for growth across our markets.

It should therefore be no surprise that we're not changing our strategy. We will continue to focus on Asia, Africa and the Middle East. We will continue to invest for growth and we will continue to be obsessed with the basics of banking, balancing the pursuit of growth with disciplined management of costs and risks, keeping a firm grip on liquidity and capital.

The strength of our balance sheet remains a powerful source of competitive advantage. We're well capitalized, already exceeding Basel III requirements, and highly liquid, both in local currencies and in U.S. dollars. We're a leader in the internationalization of the renminbi.

To give you more of a sense of how we're running the bank, I thought I'd highlight a few themes that run through our strategy. First, continued investment for growth. Whilst we've delivered positive jaws of over 2% in the first half of 2012 and maintaining our guidance for flat to positive jaws for the year as a whole, we are continuing to invest at pace in both businesses. Indeed, given the opportunities we see arising from the turbulence and the disarray of our competitor, we're stepping up the pace of investment. Most of this is to fuel organic growth.

Whilst we do look out for acquisitions to build scale, gain market access or gain critical capabilities, the primary driver of growth is organic investment in our businesses. For example, we continue to invest in building out our distribution networks in key markets. To give you a sense of the pace of the expansion in China, this slide, which shows 87 branches as at the end of June, is already out of date. Last week, we opened our 90th branch in Dalian, having opened our 88th and 89th in Changsha and Tianjin a couple of weeks ago. In fact, I was there for the opening of the Changsha branch. We expect to reach 100 branches in China by the time we announce the full year results early next year.

In India, we now have 94 branches, considerably more than any other international bank. And we also expect to hit 100 mark there by the same time. At this point, we will be present in 43 cities across India.

In Africa, where we currently have 183 branches across 14 markets, we're also significantly stepping up the pace of network expansion and anticipate that we will have some 250 branches or so within the next couple of years.

Expanding our distribution is not just the bank branches. We've been increasing investment in mobile and Internet channels. For example, Breeze, our suite of award-winning retail banking apps, is now available in seven markets. In fact, in consumer banking, we now offer mobile banking in 33 markets, Internet banking in 29, and are rolling out new products and services at pace.

But technology-driven innovation isn't just about electronic channels. We're also investing in standardized platforms across our markets and in both businesses. This is crucial to achieving continuous improvements in productivity, high levels of system stability, better risk management and rapid rollout of innovation.

The benefits for clients and customers are very tangible. In consumer banking, customer complaints have halved from 2009. We've also seen significant improvements in our Net Promoter Score, the measure of those customers who would positively recommend us.

The benefits for productivity are equally impressive. Through automation, hubbing and process reengineering, we are driving continuous improvement in cost efficiency. For example, in trade finance, the number of transactions processed per employee have increased by 35% since 2008, while over 95% of cash payments are now electronically initiated.

By making ourselves more productive, we maximize headroom to keep investing in innovation. Again, using trade finance as an example, we've rolled out a standardized state-of-the-art platform we call Trade Port, maximizing straight-through processing rates and providing better risk management through centralized management trade limits and utilizations.

In May, we executed the world's first end-to-end automated trade finance transaction using SWIFT's Bank Payment Obligation concept through our Straight2Bank platform. This electronically matches documentation between banks on either end of the trade flow, enabling faster payment for goods and quicker shipping. This kind of innovation is critical, since trade finance is at the core of Standard Chartered. From the outset of the financial crisis, our trade finance income has more than doubled from $470 million in the first half of 2008 to $958 million at the end of June, a compound annual growth rate of 19%.

International commercial banking, trade, cash, lending, FX is the heart of our wholesale banking franchise. Our strength in facilitating cross-border trade and investment explain our continued success in our Americas, UK and Europe region. Indeed, it might seem a bit odd that we've delivered such rapid income growth in the West, both in this first half, up 26% year-on-year and by a compound annual growth rate of 28% over the last five years.

This is not about us drifting into doing domestic business in such markets. It's purely about winning market share and facilitating trade and investment between Europe and the Americas and our core markets. We're helping German companies sell cars in China, Indian companies make acquisitions in the UK, U.S. or French companies raise capital from Asian investors.

A good example is BP's renminbi bond in September 2011, a first for BP and actually the first ever renminbi bond lifted in London. We acted as joint lead manager and book runner and also assisted BP in remitting the proceeds onshore to mainland China.

We manage wholesale banking as a network, not as a collection of individual geographies, identifying key trade and investment corridors and deploying resources to capture the opportunities. For example, we are uniquely placed to facilitate the explosive growth in trade and investment between China and Africa. No other bank has both a large network and deep relationships in China and a large network and deep relationships in sub-Saharan Africa.

Over the last decade, China's trade with Kenya has grown 30 times, with Nigeria, 18 times, with Ghana, 19 times. In fact, trade between China and sub-Saharan Africa has risen 20-fold in the same period, from just under $6 billion to nearly $110 billion.

In July, we brought the leadership of our African businesses to Beijing to meet senior leaders, media and clients. In fact, of the 300 business leaders from Africa attending the recent forum on China-Africa Cooperation, hosted by Premier Wen Jiabao, 20 were from Standard Chartered, the single-largest group by some margin.

This is a good example of how we're building our business in China. We're sticking to what we know and where we can add value. In wholesale banking, we are focusing on assisting the state-owned enterprises as they reach out overseas, such as to Africa, and supporting multinational corporate as they exploit the opportunities of China's growth and above all, on working with China's new and rapidly growing private sector companies, since these are often undeserved by the local banks and represent the future of China's economy.

We have no exposure to local government investment vehicles, don't try to compete for vanilla local currency business for the big state-owned enterprises and our commercial real estate exposure is minimal.

Likewise, in consumer banking, we focus on SMEs and more affluent individuals, what we call the high-value segments. We are not yet making profits in consumer banking in China as we invest in building out the business at pace, but the number of active customers in the high value segments grew 31% in the first half of 2012.

We're also leveraging the trade investment links across Greater China, exploiting our presence across the Mainland, Hong Kong and Taiwan. Whilst wholesale banking income in China grew by 25% in the first half of 2012, China network income, booked elsewhere, much of it in the rest of Greater China, grew by 56%.

As the business develops, so too does the way we manage risk. We are continually investing to enhance our risk management infrastructure and capabilities. But our fundamental approach to risk has stayed consistent over many years. We remain cautious and on the lookout for trouble. We haven't changed our risk appetite and don't plan to. We're extremely watchful about the current environment, about the way our markets and clients are responding to the global macro developments, about the potential second or third order consequences of possible stress events like further strains in the Eurozone.

We have seen some increase in loan impairments in both businesses, but from very low levels and we remain very comfortable with the shape and quality of our loan book. In fact, it's at times like these when the relationships between a bank and its clients really gets tested. We know our clients very well. Many of our relationships go back decades or generations. We stand by them through good times and bad. That's what we did in the Asia crisis in the late '90s, through the SARS epidemic in 2002, throughout the global financial crisis in 2008-2009 and it's what we're doing now.
